entry.title: May Things - Afternoon Acres, Xi‚Äôan Food, and QP Trip

link.title: May Things - Afternoon Acres, Xi‚Äôan Food, and QP Trip

entry.content:
May 6, 2023 - May 28, 2023

Still jetlagged from Japan, Esha and Kelvin had a big and early breakfast at Philippine Bread House consisting of the longsilog combo, veggie lumpia, BBQ pork skewer, ube hopia, mongo bread, and large coffee blend!

After eating their fill, they got ready to board the bus to Afternoon Acres, but it either left early or never showed up. Kelvin managed to get the address from Dave though, and they cheerfully drove up to Chester themselves. Somehow they managed to beat the bus by an hour(???), so the two of them got their hands dirty (literally) and helped pull weeds in the field around the spring garlic and garlic chives. They made a sizable pile and impact, feeling vigorous on the gorgeous day.

When everyone else finally arrived, Esha and Kelvin washed up and got served a hearty lunch of veggies picked from the greenhouse, chicken and chickpea corn patty, and fresh fruit. Kelvin tried an extra radish pulled straight from the ground that was slightly spicy.

After the meal, everyone received some potted herbs - cilantro, parsley, and basil - to grow at home, and Dave gifted the two of them a bag of garlic chives in return for the weedwork. Later in the week, Esha used them to make jap chae and gave some back to Dave, who was very impressed and asked her for the recipe to make for Whealth Kitchen meal delivery! It also went very well with Kelvin‚Äôs slow-cooked kalua pork.

In one of the best food discoveries of 2023, Kelvin found Bites of Xi‚Äôan in East Village while browsing Maps, and wow was it the real deal. The two of them ordered hot oil hand-ripped noodles, pork roujiamo, liang pi, and cold spicy chicken. The noodles were the star, with such authentic spice flavor that drastically outshown Xi‚Äôan Famous Foods, prompting Kelvin to leave his first ever Google review.

Right across the street, they also found Sundaes and Cones, which had tons of delicious asian ice cream flavors (Thai tea, lavender, and pink grapefruit), perfectly soothing their tongues after dinner. Together, they formed an S-tier one-two combo of an NYC meal. In the month of May, Esha and Kelvin would return twice more to get their Northern Chinese fix, sometimes flexing XFT for dessert (woe be sugar intake limits).

The rest of the month was marked mostly by TOTK couch degeneracy and multiple struggles to get One Cup Tea for Esha (don‚Äôt go on Sundays!).

Kelvin had a work trip to Austin, where QP HQ had redecorated with photos from last year‚Äôs holiday party. The Lloydbros also had Cabo Bob‚Äôs Burritos for the first time, which was like a better Texas version of Chipotle. Kelvin made a note to try all the different types of tortillas one day.

Back in NY, Kelvin dragged Esha to Vietnamese food, but despite his best efforts, they found nothing close to PPL and decided that NYC was just not the place for it.

Taiyaki NYC was pretty good and colorful, and they did finally manage to succeed at getting OCT popcorn chicken combo again.

In Fort Lee, the two of them tried Old Shanghai Soup Dumplings, which were different from Joe‚Äôs but tasty in their own right, and at home they did some meal prep of chicken shawarma, braised pork shank (ti pang), green onion pancake, and soy milk.

entry.title: Japan 2023 - In Which Two Old Bodies Visit Three Cat Cafes and Walk Fourteen Miles in One Day

link.title: Japan 2023 - In Which Two Old Bodies Visit Three Cat Cafes and Walk Fourteen Miles in One Day

entry.content:
April 24, 2023 - May 3, 2023

It was a long flight from Newark to Tokyo, and as comfortable as having a large snoring Samoan man asleep on one‚Äôs shoulder could be. Between pushing off the heavy advances and the mid airplane food, which Esha kept squirreling and/or forcing Kelvin to eat, they squeezed in a couple of movies. Don‚Äôt Worry Darling had an interesting premise but felt a bit lacking in its conclusion, while Catch Me If You Can was a more captivating watch (and long overdue).

When they finally landed at Narita, Esha and Kelvin made their way through some dubiously working customs machines to be welcomed by a large number of Nintendo ads.

Kelvin exchanged their vouchers for the JR Pass, and they took the NRT Express to Tokyo Station. The station was ridiculously large and difficult to find their way out of, but they eventually got above ground and headed towards their hotel in Ginza.

Kelvin called for an obligatory stop at the first Lawson they saw, and Esha quickly fell in love with Japanese convenience stores as they loaded up on onigiri, ready-to-eat veggies(!!), and fruity drinks. After checking in and getting bombarded by Kelvin‚Äôs nuclear socks, they took a much needed shower and nap, greatly enjoying the comfy hotel pajamas.

When they woke at 11 pm, they tentatively headed to Gyoza Hohei, walking through the shopping district and finding a Dior store without even trying. At the restaurant, what Esha and Kelvin thought would be a 20 minute wait for a seat was actually the wait for food, and they excitedly wolfed down a chicken ginger soup and super thin and light gyoza with garlic, chives, and ginger fillings.

They stopped by Pompadour Bakery on the walk back for some delicious tomato-filled fried pastries and were surprised by the number of people and shops open at 1 am (and, of course, how clean the streets were)!

Esha dragged Kelvin to both Family Mart and 7-11 so she could compare and contrast the store offerings. Finally, they attempted to go back to sleep as Kelvin belatedly learned some Japanese phrases from Youtube in bed.

The two of them woke up super early in the morning, so they walked to Tsukiji fish market to watch the stores open and get ahead of the crowds. As they browsed the food stalIs, they munched on a fish cake skewer with shrimp and scallop, tamago chunks, and egg milk drink.

Esha and Kelvin settled on breakfast at Kouragumi Tsukiji as it opened, ordering a delectable sea urchin and salmon roe bowl, grilled eel, abalone, and scallop with even more sea urchin. They enjoyed the fresh seafood with copious amounts of free green tea, and by the time they were finished eating, the restaurant was completely full with a line waiting for their seat.

After their meal, they walked through the rest of Tsukiji to Namiyoke Shrine, home to two stone dragon heads, and were enticed by inari and wagyu skewers, though they decided against more food for the moment.

Next, they visited Hamarikyu Gardens for some beautiful views of the seawall and southern Tokyo. Esha and Kelvin did a small squats workout by the water, and as they continued over the Umiteozutai bridge, they were surprised to see blue jellyfish of different sizes floating in the pond! As they took photos and videos, an epically huge school of fish swam by as well.

Past a couple more bridges and some old falconry bells, they arrived at Nakajima-no-ochaya, where they indulged Kelvin‚Äôs old man hobby of relaxing by the water with matcha and white bean cake.

Unfortunately they couldn‚Äôt rest for long, since 10 am rolled around, and the two of them had to hustle over for Dior‚Äôs opening. Esha was a woman on a mission, taking advantage of the Yen-USD exchange rate to purchase a very discounted Lady Dior while simultaneously giving her SA the most efficient commission/time ever. As they left the store to head to lunch, they were caught off guard by the employees‚Äô 3-pronged 90¬∞ deep bow.

Over to Shinjuku, they met up with Jenny and David at the FMA pop-up cafe at Paselabo Tower. Kelvin was deeply disappointed with Esha‚Äôs anime memory as they perused the novelty shop, and he had to reintroduce her to Roy Mustang‚Äôs cardboard cutout. When they got their table, they all ordered Edward-themed drinks and opened collector coasters - Kelvin got the Elric brothers, while Esha got Chinese people she also couldn‚Äôt remember. Everyone enjoyed some Armstrong curry and Winry apple pie, and then David went back to work when they couldn‚Äôt decide on second lunch.

Jenny joined Esha and Kelvin for the afternoon, starting with a walk to Tokyo Metropolitan Government building, on which Kelvin annoyed her with his gaijin drifting to the right side of the street. They took the elevator to the 45th floor observation deck for some great views of the city, though Mt. Fuji was of course hidden behind the clouds.

Second lunch was finally agreed upon, and the three of them made their way to Ebisu Ramen Kamuro for paitan, which was incredibly delicious and Esha‚Äôs first experience at a ticket vending machine restaurant.

After stuffing themselves, they rode the subway to Harajuku, and Kelvin further embarrassed the local by paying cash for tickets and dropping coins all over the floor. They did a short hike to Meiji Jingu, where he correctly prayed to the shrine despite Jenny‚Äôs misinformation on bowing procedure, and when it started to drizzle, the girls took the chance to do some makeup shopping at the nearby department stores.

When Kelvin began to doze off, Esha had the best idea of the day - cat cafe! David rejoined the three of them at nearby Mocha Cat Cafe, and they enjoyed unlimited drinks, manga to read, and SO MANY KITTIES. The cafe had great decor, especially the central cat tree and hanging platforms, and even the bathroom wall was lined with portraits of the cafe cats. Kelvin pet Firefly the orange kitty for a long time, and Esha reprimanded him for being annoying and poking the toe beans while Firefly‚Äôs head was in a lamp.

Eventually, they all said goodbye to the cats and made their way back to Ginza Six to eat a late dinner at Nakamura Tokichi. They had delicious matcha parfaits with so many fun layers and matcha soba with tofu, whose super bouncy noodles and seasoned tofu were an instant favorite for Esha. Way too stuffed, they decided against Jenny‚Äôs favorite pastime of salaryman-watching, but bought some premium matcha and took a look at the bookstore upstairs until KeIvin had to crash. Esha and he were pretty proud of staying awake until 9, thinking they had done well to fight off the jet lag‚Ä¶then they woke up together at 1 am gg.

They started the (very early) morning with a study of cat genitalia, followed by a couple hours of existential crisis. Kelvin was in the shower when they received a text from their new cat sitter, who explained to them that Blossom was in fact a boy, and he had to sit down in the bathtub to collect himself. Though the news was shocking, Esha and Kelvin realized pretty quickly that Blossom‚Äôs size and behavior now made a lot of sense, and he had probably been trying to tell them his true gender identity for a while.

When they were finally able to get up to go to breakfast, it was raining out, but they were able to borrow a pair of clear umbrellas from the hotel. They felt very anime as they walked and chatted and repeatedly messed up their cats‚Äô pronouns. Esha allowed Kelvin to fulfill his dream of 7 years of eating at Yoshinoya in Japan, which turned out to be much yummier than in the US. Though they embarrassed themselves with ordering off the extensive Japanese-only menu, exploding a salad dressing packet, and getting lapped by the customers seated next to them, they very much enjoyed the beef curry and unagi dons.

Their next stop was the Muji flagship store, where Esha was like a kid on Christmas morning as they browsed floor-to-ceiling shelves of snacks, soup bases, and breads. Making their way up 6(!) floors, Kelvin and she went on a bit of a shopping spree, buying pajama sets after enjoying the comfy ones from the hotel, chopsticks because why not, and a check-in suitcase for the inevitable snack haul.

Outside, it became really humid from the summer rain, so they dropped off their purchases at the hotel, then went to Tokyo Station to make seat reservations for their upcoming Shinkansen trips. The ticket agents were very helpful, and the process easier than expected, and with that out of the way, they headed to Akihabara to see Origami Kaikan. They were wowed by the samurai-themed models and got a glimpse of the paper-making studio, then Esha had fun feeling all the different types of origami paper in the gift shop.

With a couple rolls of pretty patterns in hand, they walked on to another Paselabo Tower, passing by a Miyazaki-like shrine and torii in the middle of a city street.

Unfortunately, they hadn‚Äôt had the foresight to reserve a seat at Eorzea Cafe beforehand, and they arrived to find it completely full and booked out for weeks. Kelvin had to settle for a paladin pose photo in front of the FFXIV posters, then Esha, feeling hungry, pulled out Jenny‚Äôs recommendation list and led them to Tsukiji Gindaco for a unique croissant taiyaki with custard filling and deliciously seasoned takoyaki.

To kill time before real dinner, they browsed through the many floors of nearby Akiba department store and came away with two jackets from Uniqlo and Kelvin‚Äôs first pair of Adidas Sam Smiths to replace his stupid bubbling canvas shoes. The hunt for a good hair clip continued to bear no fruit at Daiso, though there was more pretty origami and cute home decor. Kelvin marveled at the feeling of dry socks as they walked to ÁÇ≠ÁÅ´ÁÑºÈ≥• Èßø yakitori to meet up again with Jenny and David, this time joined as well by Megan and Harris. It was nice catching up on their lives abroad and sharing FFXIV glams while devouring every imaginable chicken organ.

They saw Mocha over doggy cam and brainstormed boy names for Blossom, then after dinner they all went to 21 Ni Ice for some novel cream drinks. Esha enjoyed the mango cream flavor with coconut jelly, and Kelvin especially liked the corn flakes at the bottom. After some obligatory insta selfies inside the cramped and crowded store, and a quick pass of a nearby Don Quijote, they headed back to their hotel to prepare for an early morning trip to Nikko State Park the next day.

Esha and Kelvin rose at 6 am and hunted for breakfast before their Shinkansen ride to Utsunomiya, settling on salmon and tuna mayo onigiri and a chicken ekiben from Tokyo station. The meal made Kelvin very happy for cheap and healthy fast food, though it was somewhat offset by the Muji snacks they brought along.

As the two of them settled into their seats, they munched on garlic sauce potato chips, matcha chocolate strawberries, and fruit jellies. It was a nice clear day after the rain, and they got to see Mt. Fuji in the backdrop beyond the Tokyo outskirts!

Upon reaching Utsunomiya, they transferred to the JR Nikko line for another hour long train ride before arriving in town. KeIvin gathered some info at the tourism station and ultimately decided against visiting Lake Chuzenji this time after hearing Jenny‚Äôs horror stories of getting stuck on the one way roads. Esha and he walked through the quaint little town districts, scoping out various dessert and snack shops on the way to the World Heritage site and the famous Shinkyo Bridge.

They first hiked up to Shirato Falls and Takino‚Äôo Shrine, getting a nice workout and breathing in the fresh mountain air.

After coming back down, they went to the highly recommended Nikko Coffee for lunch, which was probably their favorite meal of the trip up to that point. Along with Nikko blend coffee and muscat tea, the cafe served unique variations of Japanese comfort foods. The delicious omu-fried-rice with rich tomato sauce really hit the spot for Kelvin, while Esha delighted in the fall-off-the-bone soft pork in slightly sweet black curry. For dessert, a chocolate gateau cake with hints of miso with ice cream that had a sorbet feel while still being creamy left them so full. They purchased some strawberry milk rice crackers and gold foil kitty bread for Jenny and David from nearby stores before returning to their sightseeing.

With combo tickets, they saw the Rinnoji temple and treasure house, which had a beautiful shoyoen behind it, and Taiyu-in temple hall, where Iemitsu Tokugawa lied. They also passed by the Gohunoto five-story pagoda and Toshugu shrine. After finishing their round of the World Heritage site, Esha and Kelvin started to hike up to Jakko Falls, but they turned back due to lack of shade and trail. Instead, they switched targets to Kanmangafuchi abyss, which was guarded by little statues which the locals had dressed in cute hats and scarves for warmth. The gorge itself was made up of interesting rock formations that looked like they were carved out by cats.

Pretty tired from the day‚Äôs activities, they slowly walked back to town, stopping at Nikko Pudding Tei for creme brulee and sakura puddings. Esha made flapping crane origami from 15 year old muscle memory and gave one to the store employees.

She and Kelvin enjoyed a long nappy ride back to Utsunomiya and Tokyo; they changed lines to Shinjuku at Omiya to get dinner at Tempura Shinjuku Tsunahachi, where Jenny and David graciously waited in line for seats for them. Kelvin ordered the basic tempura zen with regular shrimp, and Esha upgraded hers with fresh Japanese tiger prawns, which were shown and killed in front of them - a shocking experience! Esha‚Äôs guilt was assuaged by their deliciousness, as the various vegetable and seafood tempura were made hot with perfect amounts of batter.

Afterwards, Jenny led them through Ryu no Miyako Inshokugai, a bar with multiple floors of different themes, which was a total vibe. They traded food gifts before parting ways, and Kelvin unabashedly ran onto the train back to Ginza to grab a seat for Esha, whose ankle hurt after the long day of rocky hiking.

The next morning, they continued onwards to Kyoto - on the bullet train, they snacked on the amazing I‚Äôm Donut? with matcha filling and assorted snacks (those were indeed words). When a trolley came by, Esha was reminded of the Hogwarts Express and excitedly bought an onigiri bento, which had plum and pickled veggies, for only 480Y.

After just a few hours, they arrived, dropped off their bags, and took the JR train out to Arashiyama. They were immediately faced with so much street food and started going to town, buying a chocolate ice cream banana crepe (rip truffle), matcha warabimochi (so soft and chewy!), and karaage skewer.

The two of them passed by even more shops as they crossed Togetsukyo Bridge over the Katsura River to hike up to the monkey park atop Iwatayama Peak. They arrived just in time for the macaques‚Äô scheduled feeding and witnessed a delightful frenzy of antics, including a few screaming disputes.

As things calmed down, Esha and Kelvin sat by the pool, wishing they could jump in with the monkeys, then entered the cage for humans to watch others hand out peanuts and apple slices.

Back outside, they took banana pictures and admired the view of Kyoto before doting on a mama with baby macaque that had food coma‚Äôed in the middle of nursing.

After hiking back down the mountain, they grabbed a matcha milk soft serve with rice cracker ducks, which somehow disappeared when Esha wasn‚Äôt looking.

To add insult to injury, they discovered they had just missed the Zen Buddhist vegetarian lunch when they arrived at Tenryu-ji. The stroll through the temple and garden was still nice, and the latter led them to the Arashiyama bamboo grove. They passed by many women in kimonos along the photogenic forest path, and Kelvin made up the missed noms to Esha with more gyoza and a crab stick at the end.

On the ride to Emmachi station, they stood behind the conductor in the first car and got a cool view of the tracks.

Kinkaku-ji was a 45 minute walk from there, and Esha and Kelvin began to feel their age, as their leg and ankle started to hurt from the 20+ miles they had done in the last two days. They made it through a slight bit of drizzle and took some op pictures of the golden pavilion, then, after finishing the temple tour, they visited a nearby Mangetsu store for red bean filled mochi and jelly.

Kelvin found a great looking udon shop, Ichibaku Nanasai, not too far away, which had a bowl with seasonal veggies and kitsune that was so fresh and delicious, and another one with an uni cream sauce packed with flavor. The noodles were so good that Kelvin had to order a third bowl with suji curry, while Esha watched very impressed. Apparently, Kelvin impressed the restaurant staff too, as the maitre d‚Äô commented excitedly while he was in the bathroom, and Esha smiled and patted her belly. With a thank you and ‚Äúoishii‚Äù, the two of them took the bus back to the hotel, and, utterly exhausted, Kelvin snored through the night to Esha‚Äôs detriment.

Esha wanted more mochi the next day (even though they hadn‚Äôt finished their Mangetsu ones yet), so they visited the shopping mall under Kyoto Station after they managed to roll out of bed. They bought some yummy shrimp and cream corn croquettes and ate while they browsed the sweets section.

Glad that they had stopped by a Mangetsu the day before when they saw the line in the station wrap around three times, they diversified with another shop that was selling fruit-filled mochi. Though the chestnut flavor was sadly sold out, the combo special blew Esha‚Äôs mind.

With a promise to come back for more later, the two of them continued on their way to the Gion district and walked along Kamo River. They were drawn into a matcha store, where they bought tea tins for family, and then they briefly toured Maruyama Park, Yasaka-jinja Shrine, and Chion-in Temple.

For lunch, they had a reservation at Rengetsu-jaya, a ten-course tofu kaiseki recommended to them by Jenny, which was super creative in the different ways it prepared and presented the many gluten dishes. The agar was especially novel, and the stringy cheesy tofu gratin was fun to eat. Oolong tea and a sweet plum liquor that Kelvin actually liked accompanied the meal, and Esha again marveled at Kelvin‚Äôs appetite as she gave him her rice and pickles and wondered if he was miserable/hungry all the time (yes). Dessert was another red bean filled mochi wrapped in shiso leaf that Esha could not finish and Kelvin had no problem devouring.

Super impressed with the meal, they walked off their lunch to Yoshidayama, passing by the enormous Heian-jingu Grand Torii in front of Kyocera Kyoto Museum of Art.

After a semi-lengthy hike through some hilly residential areas, they managed to find Mo-an Tea House and snag two seats on the back couch without a reservation. Google Lens saved the day by translating the Japanese-only menu, and they ordered iced yuzu juice and matcha drink sets with a matcha cheesecake. They relaxed a bit, munching on their cookies and snacks while listening to the rain outside, but mosquitoes soon came to munch on them as well. In the end Esha came away with one bite while Kelvin had more than one.

They made their way down the mountain and visited Ginkaku-ji, Kinkaku-ji‚Äôs lower tier sibling, a short walk away. The garden was quite nice and refreshing in the rain, and afterwards the two of them continued down Philosopher‚Äôs Path.

Unfortunately there was no kitty sighting this time around, but they made their own luck and headed over to PuchiMarry cat cafe near Nishiki Market. Kelvin had some massive gaijin struggles as he stepped into the cafe without slippers, wore the slippers back outside to store his umbrella, then had to change slippers going back in. To top it all off, he allowed two cats to run into the reception room as he entered the kitty area. In the end though, Esha and he had a great time feeding cat popsicle to derpy ‚ÄúDavid‚Äù (who turned out to be a girl), meeting feline-corgi hybrid ‚ÄúHermione‚Äù, and fanboying Koromo, the cutest folded-ears orange kibbie. They scritched some cats to sleep and witnessed many sploots and also a cat sex dungeon.

After feeding time, they headed back to the hotel, walking through Nishiki Market and getting a delicious Torikara stick and briefly considering Kura Revolving Sushi.

On their last day in Kyoto, Esha and Kelvin woke early to the pitter patter and headed to the train station, timing the rain stopping perfectly with their arrival at Fushimi Inari Shrine. There weren‚Äôt too many people yet, so they explored the shrine area a bit before starting the hike up the n-degree bad spirit filter. Esha‚Äôs outfit happened to match the bright orange torii very well!

Partway up the mountain, they met a stray black cat, which was the moment Esha had been waiting for the entire trip. She proudly busted out her bag of Temptation snacks, and their new void friend wolfed down half of it while many strangers stopped and watched.

After finally cutting him off for fear of his health, Esha and Kelvin continued to a clearing before the big loop trail, where they enjoyed inari on Inari made with delicious sesame seed rice and a soy bean flour soft serve.

While exploring the rest of the mountain, they came across a number of foxes in scarves and a real tiny frog, as they struggled to get pictures without other tourists in them.

When the two of them finished their hike, they headed back to Kyoto Station, where Esha got two more of her favorite mochi ever and also finally a satisfactory (but overpriced) hair clip, and then continued on to Nijo Castle. Esha was suddenly hit with a(nother) gyoza craving, and Kelvin found Ebisugawa Gyoza Nakajima, a small hole in the wall restaurant with an amazing lunch set. They devoured the dumplings, chashu, and veggies and learned to mix the optimal gyoza sauce.

Nearby was a funny shop called Banana Juice for Human by Gorilla, where Kelvin bought a chocolate chip banana milk and got yelled at by gorilla while ordering.

Over at the castle, they toured the inside and learned about shogun v. emperor politics and symbolism of power shifts through the architecture. They got a nice view of the surrounding moat and gardens from a watchtower, then they walked to Kyoto Gyoen to see the outside of the Imperial Palace. There were some locals walking their big fuzzy doggos.

The doggos drew Esha and Kelvin‚Äôs attention until 5 pm rolled by, and they hit up Kikyo Sushi at opening time. It was a good thing they did, since at 5:22 people started getting turned away without reservations. They went hard, ordering Sakura and Kikyo sushi sets with extra toro and uni nigiri. Kelvin loved the toro and chutoro, and the salmon and amberjack had great mouthfeel. Esha found the snapper a bit stringy but really enjoyed the uni, roe, and rest of the sushi, showing her huge progress in learning to eat raw fish over the last year.

Very satisfied, they returned to their hotel to rest their feet (and Esha‚Äôs old lady hip) before heading back out at night to a special To-Ji Temple light-up. They loved the surreal views and cool reflection shots, as Esha creeped behind some pro photographers to find the best camera angles.

The trip back crossed the 14(!) mile mark for the day, and the two of them snacked on salt and nori chips, sakura gummies, and Spy x Family Hi-Chew to reward/recuperate their broken bodies before washing up and passing out.

Esha and Kelvin checked out the next morning, bought the last pack of sakura gummies from Family Mart, and took the JR train to Nara. They stored their bags in a convenient coin locker at the station and headed to the park, passing by lots of street food and shops on the way. Kelvin wanted a melon pan with pistachio ice cream, which was so warm, sweet, and flaky, like a cookie made of bread.

When they got near Kofuku-ji, it was instantly deer! Kelvin bought two stacks of crackers and taught Esha to bow before feeding, and they laughed watching the deer emote spam back.

Before long, they found themselves again facing a 3-pronged 90¬∞ deep bow attack, but this time there was lasting damage, as one particularly aggro boy chomped on both Kelvin‚Äôs pants and Esha‚Äôs leg. She left with a red mark and became a strong advocate for deer safety. With the crackers gone, they had a more relaxed time giving pets and scritches to a resting herd. Kelvin‚Äôs no-ears didn‚Äôt quite work but he enjoyed the cute ear flaps nonetheless.

For lunch, they sat down at Mizuya Chaya and ordered delicious cold udon with veggies, a side of lightly fried karaage, and ice green tea milk. They ate by the stream and witnessed a deer come looking for food and grab a piece of paper off a nearby couple‚Äôs tray. She tried a shrimp tempura too but found it untasty and spit it out.

In the afternoon, Esha and Kelvin saw some awkward teenage deer with half-shed spotted coats hanging out with their parents near the temples.

Before leaving Nara, they strolled down a shopping street, picking up some Amarou strawberry soft serve, yuzu juice and Bonbon biscuits, and a premium pack of delightfully roasted gyokuro leaves.

They got their luggage back from the coin locker and took the Shinkansen to Osaka; as usual, they got lost in the train station for a while before finding their way to E Street and their hotel. There were too many food options in the bustling neighborhood, and in his decision paralysis Kelvin semi-seriously suggested Kura, and Esha agreed to put their names down while they browsed. Somehow they didn‚Äôt see the translations for the waitlist screen, and they submitted as a party of two children. As they browsed the rest of E Street, they came upon a stand up shop selling 500Y katsudon, which Kelvin happily ordered. They demolished the deliciously hearty meal well within the Kura wait time.

When they did get seated at the revolving sushi bar, they had fun picking out a bunch of specials and legit sushi that they wouldn‚Äôt have dared order back in the states. The salmon belly and marinated aged tuna were quite enjoyable, as well as the shrimp-avocado-crab Demon Slayer collab. Beef and pork nigiri were solid too, and the corn mayo roll was a sleeper. Kelvin ordered a JP exclusive rice coke drink and made the mistake of putting it back on the conveyor belt to take a picture‚Ä¶luckily no one was sitting at the end table as Esha ran to retrieve it. For all the work and embarrassment, the drink tasted exactly like coke with rice. Not sure what Kelvin expected. Eventually they finished their feast - overall, Kura was quite good compared to the restaurants in the U.S., but it was mid for Japan - only 132Y per plate though!

Afterwards, they explored the shops at Osaka Station, including the One Piece and Nintendo stores. Esha considered buying lots of Zelda merch but ultimately settled on a super cute Pikmin shirt.

When the stores closed, they walked over to Umeda Sky Building and took the elevator to the 34th floor, followed by a cool escalator up to the sky deck. The two of them enjoyed the nighttime view of Osaka and the pretty, albeit confusing, animation that played on the TV. They browsed the gift shop for a bit then finally went back to the hotel to hydrate Esha (no rabies pls) and sleep.

In the morning, they went back to Osaka Station for some Mister Donut, ordering matcha mochi and custard donuts to try. Unfortunately, they did not compare to I‚Äôm Donut? and were definitely overhyped online.

Kelvin also discovered that the Museum of Housing and Living was closed, so Esha and he skipped getting off the train at Temma Station and rode the JR loop around to Osakajokoen. They walked leisurely towards Osaka Castle, passing by Osaka-Jo Hall and a couple of tree groves.

At the pier, they bought timed tickets for the golden gozabune ride before crossing the bridge and climbing up to the castle park. The line outside the castle was ridiculously long, so Esha and Kelvin gathered around some street performers instead. They watched a very talented yo-yo player for a while, as well as a one-man percussion section with a traditional long horn.

The rest of the park was quite serene and home to many birds - some were having a girls day out while others were hard at work building nests over the small pond. Esha and Kelvin then took the 20 minute gozabune ride around the inner castle moat. They saw the human face rock disease and learned that northeast was an unlucky direction (RIP NY). There were more birds and some turtles sunbathing by the shore, and Osaka Castle was particularly photogenic from the boat.

After their tour, they headed to Namba Station and Dotonbori Street, where their first stop was Hanamaruken Namba Hozenji. Esha and Kelvin ordered one of their famous pork rib ramen, one ‚Äúhappy‚Äù ramen, and a side of gyoza. Kelvin ended up eating half of Esha‚Äôs noodles since they were so delicious, and they happily slurped up all of the savory pork bone broth.

They continued their walk down Dotonbori Main Street and lined up for Kururu Kuromon Museum upon spotting the signature giant octopus above the storefront. However, unlike Kelvin‚Äôs experience seven years ago, this time the takoyaki was super watery and couldn‚Äôt even be picked up without falling apart. Quite disappointed, they learned their lesson to check (and believe!) recent reviews before deciding to order.

The two of them moved on to Shinbaishi and shopped at the big Daiso, where they went back and forth on buying more cute origami paper, which turned out to be only 110Y.

To complete the trifecta, they visited Neko Tails for 3/3 cat cafes per city. This one was a unique experience with bean bag chairs and blankets for each customer, and the owners came around to place cats in people‚Äôs laps. Esha and Kelvin had a relaxing time feeding and petting all the nappy kitties and leafing through the book of lap sit ratings.

Afterwards, Kelvin made a stop for Cremia Ice Cream, made with super creamy Hokkaido milk, and Esha got an iced coffee with lemon jelly that was surprisingly good as well. The two took a walk along Dotonbori River as the sun set, reflecting on their travels and time in Japan, and loaded up on snacks before heading to the hotel, grabbing their bags, and taking their last Shinkansen back to Tokyo.

For the final half-day, Esha and Kelvin woke up extra early and still had to book it to TeamLab Planets in Chuo City. Despite getting lost looking for a seemingly non-existent subway entrance, they got there for their time slot and were ushered into the locker room.

With bare feet and rolled up pants, they entered the first water area, walking upstream through some cool ambience to a waterfall.

In the next room, they hopped, flopped, and rolled through a bean bag room, which was great fun as they watched others struggling around them.

Through the exit, they arrived into the insta-famous hanging LEDs display. The sequences of lights cycled through sparkly forest, musical rainbow, and Star Wars warp speed, which were all greatly accentuated by the surrounding mirror geometry.

After taking many photos between the light threads, and starting to get conscious about the time, they continued on to their favorite room, a koi projection ‚Äúpond‚Äù with very soothing music.

They lingered for a good while chasing fish before heading through a maze of big balloon balls.

The last section of the water area was a rotating kaleidoscope dome of flowers, which made for some epic videos (but trippy photos).

The garden half of TeamLabs was a lot shorter and included a silver eggs display and hanging flower garden.

Esha and Kelvin crawled through the lively vines to arrive back at the lockers, where they retrieved their shoes then rushed to meet up with Jenny and David for one last meal near Tokyo Station. They ordered Italian food for a change of pace and grabbed terrace seats on the 7th floor of the Marunouchi building. The sea bream broccolini pasta and large margherita+ pizza were deliciously prepared, and the dough super soft.

After lunch, they browsed Character Street together and obtained more snacks before Esha and Kelvin had to catch the NRT Express and say their goodbyes.

At the airport, Kelvin went on a long but unsuccessful mission for Hibiki/Yamazaki whiskey for Joel (RIP bonus). The flight back home was more spacious, and Esha and he watched The Tunnel to Summer, the Exit of Goodbyes and The Whale, which were both uniquely artistic and emotional. They caught some z‚Äôs, whined about how the Japanese airline food was notably better, and shared in their excitement to get back to their girl AND BOY kibbies.

A final summary of Esha and Kelvin‚Äôs Japan walk-a-thon:

And overall cat cafe rating: Kyoto > Tokyo > Osaka.

entry.title: Cheap Eats NYC
entry.content:
April 2023

Esha and Kelvin found out through the powers of ‚ÄúSFbruhs‚Äù that Julian and Yukari had been living in NJ/NY for the past two years. Flabbergasted, they all met up in midtown for lunch at Barn Joo and caught up over a delicious sake flight and way too much Korean food. They talked about work post-PhD, B&B(&B), and asked Yukari for recs for Esha and Kelvin‚Äôs upcoming Japan trip.

After packing up and fighting over who would take the leftovers, they went over to Macy‚Äôs for some shopping. The department store had its annual Flower Show on display, with elaborate themed backdrops and outfits in its windows. Among the many shops and decor on the ground floor, the Miss Dior Rose Harvest stood out, and they had a fun time smelling all the different perfumes interspersed between rose bushes. Esha was won over by the simple but classic J‚Äôadore Eau de Parfum, which she later bought from Sephora.

They continued up and down the rest of the floors, looking at some jeans and a cute top from Ralph Lauren, but ultimately not succeeding in lowering any bank accounts. After parting ways with Julian and Yukari, Esha and Kelvin headed south through Madison and Union Square Parks. They stopped by the Harry Potter store since Kelvin was in the middle of Hogwarts Legacy and had fun comparing the characters‚Äô wands/chopsticks. There was even a dungeon-like basement with a spiral staircase that reminded them of the headmaster‚Äôs office.

They skipped the butterbeer this time due to calorie concerns and were almost tempted again by Max Brenner around the corner, but the two of them held strong. They made it all the way south of Chinatown to their target Michaeli Bakery, where they bought a chocolate babka for comparison with Breads and a classic alfajores package for good measure. Although the snacks were for them to take home, Esha and Kelvin‚Äôs appetites were whetted, and they were intrigued by a tofu store Fong On a few blocks over. They enjoyed a tofu dessert with boba, red bean, and taro balls that was right up Kelvin‚Äôs alley and a bottle of the best soy milk they had had in the states.

Afterwards, they went to SJFZ (yes it‚Äôs an acronym now) for dumplings and new steamed buns! Everything was delicious as always, and they went home stuffed and PTFO‚Äôed.

A week later, Kelvin suffered a really bad stomach bug, and Esha had to drive him to the ER in the middle of the night. After he recovered, and inspired by Fong On, Esha began home-making soy milk to replace his dairy intake. It was hard work filtering out the milk from the blended soybeans, but the end result was quite tasty, and the process resulted in some bonus goodies of tofu skin and soy bean paste pancakes (made with veggies and cilantro-chili oil)!

To replenish the many lost nutrients, Kelvin also instigated an impromptu weekday night Chinatown trip. He satisfied his Taiwanese food craving with chicken leg and pork chop rice bowls from May Wah Fast Food and discovered Esha‚Äôs new favorite boba shop One Cup Tea, where they enjoyed a watermelon yakult drink and popcorn chicken.

Since they were in the area, they swung by SJFZ again for some frozen pork and cabbage dumplings to take home; sadly, they had just run out of frozen buns. Back at the apartment, Esha wanted to watch The Devil Wears Prada, and Kelvin never says no to a movie with Anne Hathaway. There was a surprising lack of Prada though, and the boyfriend was a loser.

Before heading to Japan, there were a few more food appointments for Esha and Kelvin to make. Kelvin wanted to try Prince&I, a hole-in-the-wall Thai fusion restaurant in downtown JC, which they walked to on a Friday evening. It featured healthy and very Instagrammable dishes like crab cake crepe and chicken rice bowl not pad thai, as well as yummy red bean bingsu drinks.

Later that weekend, they also enjoyed a meal with Esha‚Äôs co-worker Muhtasham, who was visiting from Munich. They went to Saray Cuisine in Cliffside Park, which apparently has a large Turkish community, and had their first experience with some more authentic dishes such as iskender with two types of eggplant appetizers and lebni. Accompanied by Turkish teas, it was a very flavorful and filling dinner, though not quite up to Muhtasham‚Äôs native standards. Afterwards, they had breads and sweets (rice pudding, trileche, and baklava) from the nearby sister bakery as they discussed ASICs, NLP, and Muhtasham‚Äôs plans in America.

Back in NYC, Esha and Kelvin did a cheap eats food tour starting from Los Tacos No. 1 and passing through SoHo for the usual RealReal and Muji stops. They realized they had missed Joe‚Äôs Pizza, so Kelvin pointed them towards Nolita Pizza instead, which had a comparatively crispier crust and very clean taste.

At One Cup Tea, Esha ordered her same combo, while Kelvin got a peach oolong tea with lychee jelly and Taiwanese sausage, and with the third trip being the charm, they finally got their hands on frozen buns from SJFZ (25 for only $11)!

Mrs. Maisel new season binge and a nice dinner date at Willow before Katherine and Chichi‚Äôs housewarming brought the two of them to their much anticipated vacation, which simultaneously felt like it had crept up on them out of nowhere - time really flies these days‚Ä¶

Also they received the cutest and most accurate B&B keychains from Cyvina :3

entry.title: Lynbros and Our Nation‚Äôs Beloved Kappital

link.title: Lynbros and Our Nation‚Äôs Beloved Kappital

entry.content:
March 2023

March marked the beginning of Esha‚Äôs new handbag saga, which involved many trips to Neiman Marcus at the Short Hills mall. For Kelvin, this meant trying more restaurants in the NJ suburbs, such as new Greek favorite Souvlaqueria and the only Mongolian BBQ in Northeast NJ, Magic Grill.

PJ and Vyas also came to stay in Brooklyn this month, and Esha and Kelvin got to see them a few times and catch up. On a Sunday morning, they endured some MTA struggles before arriving at Cheryl‚Äôs Global Soul for brunch. Kelvin ordered the buttermilk pancakes, which were fantastically fluffy, but he ultimately regretted not getting Esha‚Äôs cracked crispy fried chicken sandwich. Gotta remember that good shops can make fried chicken actually juicy‚Ä¶

After their meal, Esha and the three Lynbrook bros wandered around Prospect Park, then stopped by Doughnut Plant on the way up to Dumbo. They tried the peanut butter and strawberry jam yeast-raised donut, tres leches cake donut, and matcha green tea Wonder Wheel doughnut ice cream sandwich.

Needless to say, it was an excessive amount of sugar that even Kelvin struggled to finish, but they walked it off while taking pics of the Brooklyn Bridge and scoping out the roof of Time Out Market New York. Since PJ had to leave early for a party in Manhattan, he bought a quick burger from Pat LaFrieda, which Kelvin shared a bite of, then the remaining three of them got a low-key dinner at Saketumi Asian Bistro.

Esha rode a lot of trains in the following weeks, as she had to go to Hartford once more for work - at least this time, she got to see Phoebe and Leon while they were on vacation, and they ate delicious garlic bread and pasta at Salute together. She brought back some bread for Kelvin, who traded her his own homemade pesto chicken and pasta.

The next morning, the two of them rode Amtrak down to Washington, D.C. for their first east coast cherry blossom season. They shopped around the vendor tables in Union Station for a bit, then walked towards their AirBnB near Lincoln Park. The slight rain was rather comforting, and they found quite a few cherry trees, and the first of many duck couples, as they passed through Lower Senate Park.

After checking in, Esha and Kelvin did some quick sightseeing of the Capitol building, Library of Congress, and Supreme Court. They made their way up to Chinatown for lunch, ordering dim sum and popcorn chicken to go from China Boy, and stumbling upon the Washington Justice practice facility in search of boba.

With the optimal snack combo in hand, they waited in line for the National Archives Museum, next to an impressive parade of food trucks on Constitution Ave. More lines later, Esha and Kelvin finally got to see the Declaration of Independence, Bill of Rights, and Constitution, but they were completely illegible from fading. They GTFO‚Äôed to Warner Theatre for the Cherry Blossom Festival opening ceremony, which was pretty cute and had a nice lineup of Japanese musical artists. Kelvin particularly enjoyed the marimbist Mika Stoltzman, and Travis Japan (and their fangirls) were entertaining to watch.

Sunday was sunnier, and the two of them walked down Independence Ave to the Washington Monument and National Mall. The blossom kite festival was in full swing there, and Esha and Kelvin spent a while hanging out under the cherry trees staring at the numerous kite designs and thinking about making a giant Vaatu. They eventually got up to see Floral Park and make their way around Tidal Basin, which was very pretty under the clear blue sky and inhabited by multiple additional duck couples. However, the area was so insanely crowded that Esha and Kelvin were often forced onto the muddy dirt paths, and after struggling through half of the loop, they decided to take a break for lunch.

They found an oyster bar on the wharf and experienced the slowest service of all time, taking two hours to get and pay for their meal of fried shrimp and kimchi fried rice.

At that point, they were apprehensive of returning to the cherry blossom crowd, so they headed north past Constitution Gardens to the White House lawn instead. Esha‚Äôs last request for their DC trip was another popcorn chicken, but on their way back to Chinatown, they ran into more random unpleasantness from cranky old bike lady and ‚ÄúChris Rock‚Äù, who very understandably confused Kelvin for Bruce Lee (it was a compliment though!). They finally made it back to Union Station, where Kelvin celebrated his newfound stardom with a tiramisu milkshake from Shake Shack, and headed home from one of the trips of all time.

At least L‚ÄôArtusi with PJ and Vyas was fun. Can‚Äôt beat that beet salad, and Bucatini Nero and hen of the woods Roasted Chicken were perfectly crafted. Olive oil cake finale made them wish they could have stayed longer!

entry.title: Valentine‚Äôs Noms
entry.content:
February 2023

February was a month of new cooking and new eats. Kelvin refined a tofu stew recipe with konjac and napa cabbage, and Esha recreated the miso sesame tofu they had liked from Her Name is Han.

They also tried Sugarfish in NYC, which had a (Nozawa) Trust Me sushi lunch set with no tipping. While the ponzu and chives seasoning lent some interesting flavors to the nigiri, they overall felt that the fish was not as tasty as Kazunori‚Äôs, nor as cheap.

At Breads Bakery, Esha and Kelvin picked up the usual chocolate babka, while also trying their Valentine‚Äôs special white heart dessert.

A desire to level up her interior decorating skills drew Esha into various furniture and flower shops, such as Design Within Reach, where Kelvin gawked at a $10k chair, Ariston Coffee Bar, which had a wide assortment of roses (and tasty coffee), and Avocado, where Esha looked at vases while Kelvin dubiously received a bundle of dried white daisies.

For actual Valentine‚Äôs Day, the two of them attended Dave‚Äôs cooking class and received ingredients to make their own beef/veggie bolognese pastas, toasted sourdough with ricotta and honey, and caramelized pear with granola. They had a lovely evening preparing their meal together while watching Gilmore Girls and sipping on wine and spritz.

From the cooking class:

Our rendition:

On the weekend, Esha and Kelvin tried Dirt Candy‚Äôs vegetarian tasting menu, though they weren‚Äôt able to book the Valentine‚Äôs special course this year. The novel beet √©clair, savory onion chive pizza, and famous crispy butternut squash were highlights of the meal, but the other half of the menu was not too inspiring.

To fill Kelvin‚Äôs meat quota, they stopped by a skewer cart in Chinatown afterwards, where he munched on a deliciously seasoned lamb kebab, then searched frantically for his ‚Äúlost‚Äù earmuffs, only to crack up insanely on the PATH train 30 minutes later when Esha pointed to them on his arm. At home, the two of them baked yummy nutella- and pistachio cream-filled muffins.

February was Esha‚Äôs turn for a business trip, and Kelvin drove them up to CT to try a seafood restaurant, Dog Watch Caf√© in Stonington, recommended to them by Nathan. They enjoyed the bouillabaisse and fish and chips while watching a truly glorious east coast sunset on the water.

At the end of the week, Kelvin returned to pick her up and also to try the much raved about Chef Jiang, which turned out to be much better than its NYC namesake. Kelvin really liked the spicy cold dishes and squirrel fish, and Esha of course devoured a popcorn chicken and XLBs. Delicious-as-always CT ice cream from Frisbie‚Äôs Dairy Barn fueled Kelvin for the drive down to NJ.

More XLBs were had back home that weekend at Soup Dumpling Plus, along with a YOLO market price lobster crisp noodle.

That was followed up with pretty decor and even prettier matcha soft serve (in Kelvin‚Äôs opinion) at Matcha Cafe Maiko, to round out a great day of Fort Lee noms.

Finally, even B&B got some new eats this month, as Esha and Kelvin started experimenting with homemade cat food - the first batch of oven baked chicken breast, heart, and gizzard was a resounding success in their eyes (and mouths), which delighted their parents.

By Kelvin‚Äôs request, here are some bonus pics of Esha trying on Zimmermann outfits. By Esha‚Äôs decree, Kelvin is always wrong. (Honshu bathroom sign agrees!)

entry.title: Gramercy, Kansas City, QP Ski Trip

link.title: Gramercy, Kansas City, QP Ski Trip

entry.content:
January 2023

Esha and Kelvin went to the difficult-to-book Gramercy Tavern to celebrate Kelvin‚Äôs birthday. Though they were still a bit sniffly from their post-Chicago colds, they looked forward to the famous cocktails and burger. The restaurant ambience was great, as they were seated at a cozy table near the lively bar and with direct LOS to the kitchen.

Esha started off with a fruity Izakaya cocktail, while Kelvin ordered the seasonal spritz. They indulged in accidental multiple flatbreads, which were all well-baked and flavorful.

For their entr√©es, Esha got the grilled black bass, and Kelvin of course sprung for the rare Tavern Burger, which was tasty but a bit overburnt on the sesame bun. Overall, they agreed that the food was about par, but the service and vibe were definite positives.

The evening ended happily, as their waiter brought out a coconut cupcake treat for Kelvin, who made a second birthday wish after already enjoying a delicious Torico ice cream cake earlier in the week.

Since they missed Janet and Lindsay during the holidays, Esha and Kelvin also took a short trip to Kansas City, which was strangely mostly located in Missouri, to meet up with them over MLK weekend.

Their first stop after landing had to be Joe‚Äôs BBQ, where they stood in line smelling the meat for a while (a positive for everyone except Esha). They eventually got a table with their order of Z-Man and pulled pork sandwiches, alongside a full slab of pork ribs. Kansas definitely didn‚Äôt mess around with the slab size, as the four of them combined struggled to make it through all the meat. While the ribs were expertly smoked, they were not quite as flavorful as Texas BBQ, and the sandwiches were mid.

As the one meal was enough for Esha to be ‚Äúmeated out‚Äù, they checked in to their AirBnB near Union Hill and napped and Crew‚Äôed for a few hours. By the time everyone was ready to head out again, it was already dark, but that allowed for a sweet view of the National WWI Memorial, which stood out like a beacon against the sky.

Their walk continued over and through Union Station, where they learned about the history of the USPS and the railroad, and into downtown KC.

Esha and Kelvin followed Janet to their first speakeasy, Swordfish Tom‚Äôs, a rustic establishment with a variety of interesting in-house cocktails and very knowledgeable server. Esha sprung for the Blank Verse, a tasty floral cocktail with four different types of alcohol (oops), and tried sips of Janet‚Äôs very smokey whiskey.

After finishing their sufficiently strong drinks, they had a dinner reservation at Novel, which Esha had worked very hard to secure a reservation for. Unfortunately, it happened to be Restaurant Week in KC, so they were offered a smaller, albeit cheaper, menu. Esha did not get to try the lobster ramen she had been looking forward to, but the four of them still enjoyed two meal sets with scallops, salmon and roe, and slices of fruit cake and pie for dessert.

On the walk back to the AirBnB, they passed through the Crown Center Square, which was still beautifully lit up with Christmas lights.

Sunday morning started at Succotash, where Esha and Kelvin ordered the vegan (kitchen) sink and Swedish pancakes. They really enjoyed the (actual) novel twists on breakfast dishes, especially the lima bean hummus and lingonberry crepes.

Energized for the day, they headed to the Kemper Museum of Contemporary Art, which was indeed contemporary and indeed art. Some notables were a ‚Äúcat‚Äù, a ‚Äúhen‚Äù, a spider that actually looked like a spider, and a depressed giant (along with Janet).

They continued on to the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, which was less contemporary and had eight giant badminton birdies on display, though their structural inaccuracies annoyed Lindsay.

There were some interesting paintings and sculptures throughout the museum, including lots of rectangles for Kelvin, but everyone enjoyed the walk around the outside lawn the most. They encountered totem poles, a cool mirror installation, and a glass maze that Kelvin trolled Esha through.

After finishing their rounds, the four of them drove to Country Club Plaza, a historic shopping area with Southern decor and cute penguin statues great for Instagram model shots.

They bought coffees and browsed a couple candy and clothing shops, then finally for dinner, they went to Corvino Supper Club. This was unanimously the best meal of the trip, as everyone enjoyed the variety and quality of interesting fusion dishes, though they could have gone without the live band‚Äôs rock rendition of Baby Shark. The chinese broccoli with whipped tofu and chili crunch was a hit appetizer, and Kelvin loved the Thai rigatoni bolognese. Esha‚Äôs favorite main was a gnocchi with roasted squash, and gingerbread affogato and olive oil lemon pavlova rounded off the menu.

On the last morning before flying out, the gang made a stop at Christopher Elbow Chocolates, where Esha and Kelvin drank delicious hazelnut hot cocoas and bought a bunch of truffles to go.

For lunch, they had gigantic ‚Äúsalads‚Äù at The Russell, and for second lunch, Janet went next door for a final BBQ sandwich from Gates BBQ while the rest of them looked on in amazement and slight disgust.

Back in NJ, Esha and Kelvin had a quiet week of B&B cuddles, Xi‚Äôan Famous Foods and Her Name is Han with Grace, and cat sitting Noodle for Wenqiu, until Kelvin got called for an impromptu company ski trip to Telluride, Colorado.

The snowy mountains were absolutely gorgeous, and Kelvin had a fun time riding the gondolas back and forth around town. QP tech team stayed at a ski-in/ski-out cabin, and combined with the empty weekday slopes and super long runs, it made for the best skiing experience he had ever had.

A week flew by, as the team worked hard, cooked dinners, and played board games.

They were also treated to a fancy meal at Ania‚Äôs Table, where Chef made an amazing duck breast and brioche bread pudding. The team had a great time chatting with both Ania and her husband, who turned out to have lots of friends in the trading industry, and clued them in on the origins of the QP logo.

Finally, many runs of Galloping Goose later, Kelvin joined Esha back at home, and they enjoyed some Spring Caf√© and Jiang‚Äôs Kitchen in East Village.

entry.title: Christmas in Chicago
entry.content:
December 24, 2022 - December 31, 2022

For the holidays this year, Esha and Kelvin planned to fly into Chicago for a week to meet up with Kelvin‚Äôs family, who they hadn‚Äôt seen in person together in quite a while. Unfortunately, Janet and Lindsay were visiting Paris at the same time, but they graciously allowed them to stay at their place, and Kelvin‚Äôs family booked an AirBnB nearby. The day of Christmas Eve, Esha and Kelvin went to NYC to procure some loaves of babka from Breads Bakery, which was all the rage on an r/FoodNYC thread, to give as gifts. Since it was nearby, they also booked a reservation at Pinto Garden, which was serving some very unique Thai fusion dishes on their brunch menu. Kelvin thoroughly enjoyed a crispy pork belly congee with garlic crisps, and Esha‚Äôs Sunrise Pad Thai complemented it well.

At the bakery, they almost bought a savory bialy babka, a special collab with Smitten Kitchen, but managed to find the original chocolate ones they were after. With three babkas in Esha‚Äôs Bembien bag (one for Janet and Lindsay, one for Wenqiu and Yiqiao, and one for themselves), they still wanted more bread and went across the street to the Union Square Winter Village at the sight of a Bread Alone Bakery stand. They browsed the lively shops and restaurant pop-ups before grabbing a loaf of San Francisco sourdough (Kelvin considered sending a picture of Esha‚Äôs new BFF to SourDohee). Esha then wanted to watch Avatar The Way of Water but was embarrassed to bring her friend into the theater, so they first dropped all their breads off at home. Until the 7pm showing, they shopped around Newport Mall for some jeans and black boots for Kelvin, not realizing that the food court closed when all the stores did. Their dinner thus sadly consisted of four leftover Panda Express egg rolls, but they made up the calories by getting a bag of popcorn at the theater. They both managed to stay awake and not pee throughout the whole 3 hour 12 minute movie, and though there were a few squint-worthy plot armor points, it was a fun and beautiful experience overall.

On Christmas day, they had a short get-together with Shir, Ahalya, and Ian at their apartment. Shir picked up food from Tasty Moment on his way from home, and Ahalya, who had just come back from her postdoc in Switzerland, drove with Ian down from his family‚Äôs place in Fort Lee. They had a really nice time catching up about Ahalya‚Äôs Europe experience and work woes, and hearing about Shir‚Äôs new gf. Kelvin baked one of the babkas they had acquired, and as Esha was serving it, he took a taste of a crumb left in the toaster oven. The chocolatey goodness was amazing even in that tiny morsel, and his reaction induced the rest of the room‚Äôs excitement. Indeed, as each person bit into their slice of that gooey but crunchy, delicious bread, they were blown away by the flavor and texture and insulted that this was their first time experiencing it. Esha and Kelvin did not have very many leftovers and were happy knowing that they were giving some good gifts this season.

After their friends headed out, and they finished the rest of their packing, they went to the airport early in case of snafus due to Winter Storm Elliott. Expecting a busy security check and lots of standby travelers from the canceled flights preceding them, they instead were treated to 4.5 hours of delays caused by crappy gate management. They managed to entertain themselves listening to passengers from other gates applaud sarcastically for flight boardings, and a random guy yelling down the terminal ‚ÄúStop flying United they fucking suck!‚Äù Kelvin also bought a pizza and juice for them to eat while Esha learned how to play Chrono Ark, until finally they were able to get on a plane from a different gate and get on their way to Chicago. Kelvin‚Äôs joke that his family might arrive before they did almost came true, as they landed at ORD just 1.5 hours before the others‚Äô flight from SFO.

Since their Getaround booking fell through, instead of driving up to Northwestern, everyone decided to get some food in their sleep-deprived bodies at Wildberry. The line was surprisingly short, and they enjoyed taking pictures of snowflakes in each other‚Äôs hair as they waited.

Once they were seated in their cozy corner booth, they excitedly ordered white + dark chocolate banana pancakes, chorizo eggs benedict, veggie hash skillet, and the turkey chili special with a side of fries.

Everything was a hit, and it helped energize them greatly (or at least motivate them to burn off the calories), and they set off north on Michigan Ave to do some shopping. As they crossed the Chicago River into Magnificent Mile, everyone was quite impressed at the city‚Äôs Christmas decorations, and they really felt grateful to be spending the holiday time with each other.

Together, they browsed Nordstrom, still in search of black chukkas that Kelvin liked, Aesop, where Kelvin‚Äôs family tried a bunch of scented samples, skipped UGG with a line longer than Chanel (just why?), and Sephora, where Esha showed off her contouring skills on the Fang family noses. They also came across the largest Starbucks any of them had ever seen - four stories tall! Incredibly curious, they went in and toured the facility, which had coffee bars on the ground and 3rd floor, a bakery on the 2nd, and a cocktail bar on the 4th. There was even a roof terrace, which was covered in snow so unfortunately closed for the day.

After making their way back down, they decided to head back to Janet and Lindsay‚Äôs so that Kelvin‚Äôs family could check in to their AirBnB, and everyone could rest a bit before dinner. Esha and Kelvin spent their rest time trekking to Mariano‚Äôs and getting their obligatory half-gallon of freshly squeezed orange juice, now up to $6.99, and a watermelon juice as well. A glass of each later, they made their way to the green line, meeting back up with Kelvin‚Äôs family to go to Fulton Market District. They arrived early and, having some time to kill, went into Time Out Market, which Esha and Kelvin recognized from their trip to Chicago in June. Surprisingly, almost half of the restaurants seemed to be new, and after passing by each one, they all settled down on the second floor to wait until their reservation.

When the time came, everyone excitedly walked over to Girl & the Goat, where they were promptly seated. Despite the restaurant being completely packed, the service was great, and they started with drinks for Esha (you had me at aloe), Shirley (peach tea-quila), and Dad (riesling).

For food, everyone chipped in with suggestions and Yelp reviews, and they got pan fried shishito peppers, saut√©ed green beans, hamachi crudo, saut√©ed bay scallops, roasted pig face, sticky glazed pork shank, and goat empanadas to share. Although Esha had been slightly worried whether Kelvin‚Äôs family would enjoy the New American fare, she was quickly relieved to see that everyone loved the meal, with every dish eliciting wows, especially from Mom. They all had a fantastic time playing shishito pepper roulette and making pork shank wraps, while gatekeeping Kelvin‚Äôs diet. Everyone got to thoroughly enjoy their favorite dishes as they quite thoughtfully split the food according to their preferences. For Shirley‚Äôs birthday, they even got the green beans comp‚Äôed and had a surprise coffee ice cream at the end to boot.

Though since Shirley herself was not a fan of coffee, they made the easy decision to go down the block for Jeni‚Äôs Splendid Ice Creams for extra dessert. Esha and Mom were completely stuffed, but Kelvin, Shirley, and Dad split a scoop of wildberry lavender and salted peanut butter with chocolate flecks. Finally having eaten more than everyone‚Äôs fill, and quite sleepy from both travel and food coma, they all headed home to get some well deserved rest.

The next morning, everyone met at the AirBnB, and Esha and Kelvin just happened to bump into Shirley and Dad getting back from Dunkin‚Äô. They warmed up a bit inside with tea and donuts before setting out for Grant Park. At the Agora, everyone took turns copying the statues‚Äô poses and taking silly pictures.

They walked over the pedestrian bridge to the Chicago marathon finish line, then continued north, sporadically hopping in the snow and watching Shirley make a snow angel. When they reached Buckingham Fountain, they crossed Lake Shore Dr to Queen‚Äôs Landing and got an awesome view of frozen Lake Michigan. The ice was just beginning to thaw, and they could hear cracking and moaning as they stood on the shore.

At that point, people started to get hungry, so everyone walked over to Revival Food Hall to grab lunch. Esha didn‚Äôt want to make decisions, so she volunteered for table guard duty, as Kelvin browsed through the numerous options. A few minutes later, he brought back an Ayam Rica Rica from Minhasa and a mushroom broth with roast garlic broth bomb. Shirley and Dad opted for empanadas and a chicken tortilla soup, and Kelvin also helped Mom find a warm noodle soup (Soto Ayam) to eat. The Indonesian fried chicken in the Rica Rica was a bit spicy and sour, so to help balance out the flavors, he went back to Electric Greens and got a Hemp Seed Crunch Toast.

Having eaten a bit more than they intended, they eagerly got ready to continue on with their itinerary, only to find out that the Art Institute was closed. They decided to shuffle their plans a bit and visit Navy Pier that afternoon instead, but first they stopped by the CBOT, which was nicely decorated with Christmas wreaths and ornaments.

When they reached Navy Pier, they discovered there was a Light Up the Lake festival happening. The designs were pretty lit, with some large installations like a rubber ducky, deer, and teddy bear. Kelvin was annoying and got in the way of many photos, but then thankfully got distracted by the memory cube game. Without really trying, he got 7th on the leaderboard and signed his name as Fro, only to discover that 5th place was held by Ko, which seemed good enough for him.

After making their way around the festival hall, they got in line to rent ice skates, but the rink closed for cleaning, so, not wanting to miss their dinner reservation, they moved on to the ferris wheel. While the line for the elevator looked a bit scary, it was not too long before they found themselves high up above the pier, and everyone got some great shots of the city lights and skyline. Upon looking down, Esha was also reminded of the Crystal Gardens, but she was disappointed to see that it was closed for renovation too.

Everyone browsed the stores a bit after the ride, and then they took a bus to Avec. With all of the small annoyances of the day, they were pleased to find out that wine bottles were half off for Tuesday, and they ordered a Lise et Bertrand Jousset sparkling wine. They were even given a few glasses for free as the bottle was chilled!

For small plates, they got the charred cabbage, wild Mexican prawns, chorizo-stuffed Medjool dates, and hummus with baby carrots. The dates and prawns were highlights of the whole meal, and they refused the server trying to take the remaining sauce away, asking instead for an extra pita to wipe it up with. They ordered rotisserie chicken shawarma and Persian rice pilaf with lamb shoulder as mains, and they loved the garlic toum sauce, though they were shocked to discover another giant pita covering the pilaf, which they struggled to finish. Ultimately, Kelvin‚Äôs family took some leftovers home since they had already run Janet and Lindsay‚Äôs fridge out of space with babka and juice, and everyone went to bed with full stomachs and tentative plans to jog in the Chicago winter morning like crazy people.

Kelvin woke up grumpy and sleep-deprived at Esha‚Äôs 7:30am alarm and begrudgingly got dressed for his least favorite form of exercise. They met up with Dad at the AirBnB and started their jog towards Grant Park. Esha‚Äôs natural talent and lighter frame allowed her to pull ahead of Kelvin, but he kept his grit and tried his best to keep up with her and Dad. Seeing his effort, they patiently took breaks to let him catch up. Though it was painful, the scenery of the morning sun over the lakefront made the run more bearable, and the view from the still icy pier was quite breathtaking (or maybe that was just their lungs dying).

On the return trip, Dad taught Esha and Kelvin about good running habits, and Kelvin experimented with some breathing techniques and mental imagery which seemed to help. However, by the time they reached the AirBnB, his legs were dead tired, so they all went up to rest a while and let Kelvin get a drink and donut. After Esha and Kelvin showered and changed, they met back up with Kelvin‚Äôs family to walk around Millenium Park. When they had taken enough basic photos and selfies, everyone walked over to nearby Garrett‚Äôs to buy some popcorn to tide them over until dinner (no lunch allowed before Oriole). Kelvin‚Äôs family really enjoyed the cheese and sweet caramel mix, especially Mom, who kept munching all the way to Museum Campus.

Unfortunately, they found that Shedd Aquarium was out of tickets until late afternoon, and Field Museum‚Äôs line was too long. They instead took a walk around the campus by the lake and were surprised to find that nearly all the ice had thawed on that side.

Since everyone was a bit tired, they decided to go back home early to rest a bit before getting ready for dinner - Esha enjoyed a nice nap while Kelvin worked on this blog. An hour or two before their reservation time, Esha woke up and did makeup with Mom and Shirley. A bit later, the guys also got dressed, and Kelvin the Human Alarm Clock had to yell at Dad to wear something better than sneakers to Oriole - luckily, Kelvin‚Äôs boots fit his outfit pretty well, so he was able to repay the favor of borrowing Dad‚Äôs running shoes. With everyone looking quite classy, they booked an Uber and arrived just on time, though for the second time their driver was worried about the shady af drop-off location. After reassuring him that the dark back alley was indeed the right spot, they entered Oriole and came up to the familiar freight elevator/garage door. Kelvin‚Äôs family enjoyed the spectacle of the industrial waiting room opening into refined Michelin restaurant, as they were greeted by their server and had their coats taken. Their server was happy to hear that Esha and Kelvin had dined at Oriole before, and even happier to show them all the renovations it had undergone since they had last been there. While the restaurant had a cozier vibe with brick walls back in 2018, the new Oriole had a sleeker design, yet still emanated warmth with a number of fireplaces and comfortable seats. They had also significantly expanded their floorplan, and everyone was first led to the new bar area for preliminary drinks and appetizers.

Right away, Kelvin‚Äôs family was blown away by the drink pairings - the spirit-free Fresh and the Sparkling Sake that even Kelvin actively enjoyed - so much so that they forgot the pairing part and downed them before the arrival of the first food course. Mom also got overly excited and went behind the bar to take pictures of everyone with their drinks and got reprimanded by Kelvin, though the bartenders were very nice about it and even refilled their glasses. Everyone was thus able to fully enjoy the first pairing with the Sea Urchin, Carabineros, and Hiramasa, a beautiful set of three seafood small bites. The Sea Urchin started the meal off with unparalleled smoothness, while the meatier Carabineros with sauce am√©ricaine delivered the first deep punch of flavor, and the Hiramasa served to cleanse the palette and keep the appetizer portion light and anticipatory.

For the second course, everyone was led to an island in front of the open kitchen, where the chefs were busy preparing entr√©es for the night. Both Ros√© pairings were introduced as drinks with complex layers to accentuate the multidimensional, and absolutely gorgeous, Foie Gras. The huckleberries on top added sweetness to the savory pat√© and perfectly baked bread, and gold flakes found their way onto everybody‚Äôs lips, which also matched beautifully with Esha‚Äôs Zimmermann top.

After that stunning combination of flavors and colors, they were taken to their main table and introduced to most people‚Äôs favorite spirit, the Riesling Sp√§tlese, and the Odayaka. A Spiny Lobster with matching coconut and honeydew froth that was reminiscent of Kelvin‚Äôs previous favorite dish, Pike, was brought out.

At this point, the drinks began to build up, and the chain of bathroom goers started, with Esha first confirming the upgrades to those facilities as well, which included Aesop hand soap, mouthwash, and lotion. An outright umami bomb was next on the table, a cup of Matsutake soup filled with black truffle pieces and tarragon leaves. Kelvin‚Äôs favorite drink of the meal, the Toasty genmaicha, and another Sake from Miyagi were extraordinarily relaxing and perfect for balancing out the strong flavors.

For the next two courses, everyone was given a bit of seaweed butter and a bread roll for soaking up leftover sauce, a perk that seemed perfectly catered for Esha.

A Meursault white wine and spirit-free Bianco, which was cool and refreshing with more subtle fennel, accompanied the Sablefish. Kelvin‚Äôs parents got their first taste of caviar, and the oyster sauce was very fresh and intriguing.

The second to last savory course was one that Esha and Kelvin were super familiar with - the Capellini pasta, an Oriole special that was Esha‚Äôs first experience with truffle in 2018! Their anticipation while the server introduced the dish was palpable, and it turned out to be even better than they remembered, due to the new addition of crispy fried capers. The rest of Kelvin‚Äôs family thoroughly enjoyed the immense truffle flavor and perfectly cooked pasta in conjunction with the Barbaresco from Italy and chrysanthemum-infused Malty.

After everyone had meticulously scooped up every drop of sauce, a Saint-Julien red wine and Evocative shiitake consomm√© were presented, indicating the apex of the chef‚Äôs tasting experience. The climax of the meal was an absolutely delectable cut of Miyazaki Beef, served with a dollop of hakurei turnip pure√© and roasted little gem lettuce. On top of each piece of beef the server also grated a bit of real wasabi root, which was so fresh and light, with none of the sting from horseradish. The meat, along with a small cup of seasoned broth, had no hint of earthiness, and both Esha and Kelvin‚Äôs mom found it totally delicious (everybody else was a given). They all agreed that it was the best beef entr√©e they had ever tasted and craved more despite being completely stuffed at that point.

With the main courses sadly over, everyone was served a Peach three-ways palette cleanser, which turned out to be one of the most fun dishes of the night. The flavors were surprisingly complex, with an initial burst of sweetness akin to haw flakes that gave way to a lighter fizziness due to the Tasmanian pepperberries.

This transitioned into the dessert courses nicely, though to the girls‚Äô distress, the first one was a heavier Souffl√© with hot cream. Kelvin had (got) to help Esha finish the sauce in the middle, but the pastry part was too delicious to give up, especially paired with Crisp and Pear Ciders.

The final course was a spicy one, a beautiful Mont Blanc soybean tart with ginger Zesty drink and Vin Santo del Chianti Classico spirit.

And to wrap it all up, each person got their choice of tea, as well as two Bon-Bons with cute designs, though Kelvin was the only one who didn‚Äôt have to take those home.

Finally having reached the end of their 3.5 hour long meal, everyone was beyond satisfied and in need of some serious focused digestion. Esha and Kelvin reiterated to their server that after five years Oriole still remained the best dining experience ever, and Kelvin‚Äôs family was extremely pleased at their first Michelin 2 star tasting menu. Everyone went home very determined to not get up for running the next day.

After a very good night‚Äôs sleep, during which Kelvin dreamed of the Miyazaki Beef, everyone got back together at Cai in Chinatown for lunch. They kept the dim sum order fairly light, then went to Joy Yee for some dragon passionfruit and honeydew smoothies.

Everyone made their way around Chinatown Square Plaza posing with the zodiac statues and laughing at the (in)accuracies of the fortunes. From there, they walked to Ping Tom Memorial Park and took some photos at the pagoda by the river and of the murals under the 18th St bridge.

Shirley craved some baked goods, so their last stop before heading to the red line station was Chiu Quon, where they bought some wintermelon cakes, a bbq pork bun, and a red bean paste cake.

Back in River North, everyone tried their hands at Special Ops: Mysterious Market at The Escape Game Chicago. The five of them were paired with another couple and led into the game room, where Esha and Kelvin did some good work solving puzzles with canes, lights, and shoes. Dad managed to skip a step entirely to help unlock the door to the next room, then almost led everyone straight out the (false) exit. The group did less well on the second half, as there were some struggles with the flashy military screen and refueling minigame. Unfortunately, they ran out of time with two steps left to solve, though Kelvin was confident that they could have finished with just a few more minutes.

At that point, Esha and Kelvin had a dinner date with Erin, so they split off for The Cheesecake Factory while Kelvin‚Äôs family went to try Al‚Äôs Beef. The restaurant was just as Esha remembered it from her teenage years, and they had a nice time reminiscing about the last decade over their avocado egg rolls and surprisingly flavorful skinnylicious entr√©es.

After dinner, they hopped back on the red line to Wrigley Field, where the last Christkindlmarket of the season was thankfully still being hosted. With Kelvin‚Äôs family, they roamed through the winter village‚Äôs shops and food stalls, picking up the 2023 Christmas mug and some wafer snacks. When they had finished making their rounds, they all went back to the AirBnB to chill and munch on the day‚Äôs goodies before heading to bed.

Friday lunch was at Lou Malnati‚Äôs on Michigan Ave, where everyone shared two pies, The ‚ÄúLou‚Äù with sausage and a custom thin crust with spinach mix and roma tomatoes. Kelvin‚Äôs family really enjoyed the deep dish pizza and easily demolished it in their rush to make it to their tour on time.

At 1 pm, they arrived at the Chicago Architecture Center for A Walk Through Time, led by their guide Cynthia. The tour started along the river with Trump Tower and two examples of mid-century modernism, AMA/IBM Plaza and Marina City aka the Corncob Towers.
